SUMMARY: ZraR, zinc resistance-associated regulator, controls expression of genes involved in tolerance to high zinc concentrations. ZraR recognizes a DNA sequence of two inverted repeats of 17 bp separated by 12 bp [11243806]. This regulator is a member of two-component regulatory system ZraS/ZraR. operon containing both genes zraR, encoding response regulator, and zraS, encoding sensor kinase, is located next to and in opposite direction to zraP , a gene regulated by ZraR. It has been suggested that ZraS functions as a zinc receptor [11243806]. ZraS and ZraR show considerable homology with proteins NtrB and NtrC, respectively [2666400]. ZraR also belongs to group of σ54-dependent transcriptional regulators [11243806]. Members of this group contain three domains: sensory domain located in N terminus, central domain involved in ATP hydrolysis and interaction with σ54, and C-terminal domain, which contains a helix-turn-helix motif [16005641, 2666400]. A regulatory role related to activity of enzyme hydrogenase 3 has been assigned to ZraR (previously called HydG) [2666400] but it was demonstrated that this regulation was nonspecific [11243806]. Based on a crystal structure of ZraR from Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium, it has been suggested that this protein may function as a dodecamer [16005641]. Transcription of zraR is induced by zinc stress [15659689]and high levels of c-di-GMP [16418169].
